dataset.title: Water Use and flooding in central Arizona-Phoenix: comparison of water and carbon dioxide uptake by selected plant species among residential patch transition types, from 1998 to 1999.

creator.organizationName: School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University
School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University
School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University
School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University

abstract.para: Compare the primary productivity (rate of of production of plant material) and uptake of water and carbon dioxide by selected plant species, at sites selected to represent the transition between desert or agriculture and new residential development.

keywordSet.keyword: water dynamics in a desert city
keywordSet.keywordThesaurus: IPA and Core Area CAP Data Portal Controler

keywordSet.keyword: central arizona phoenix longterm ecological research

section.para: Copyright Board of Regents, Arizona State University. This dataset is released to the public and may be used for academic, educational, or commercial purposes subject to the following restrictions:

listitem.para: While CAP LTER will make every effort possible to control and document the quality of the data it publishes, the data are made available "as is".
CAP LTER cannot assume responsibility for damages resulting from mis-use or mis-interpretation of datasets or from errors or omissions that may exist in the data.
It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists that has resulted in data used in subsequent research.
CAP LTER expects that any use of data from this server will be accompanied with the appropriate citations and acknowledgments.

CAP LTER encourages users to contact the original investigator responsible for the data that they are accessing. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on CAP LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
CAP LTER requests that users submit to the Global Institute of Sustainability, ASU, one copy of any publication resulting from the use of data obtained from this site.
CAP LTER requests that users not redistribute data obtained from this site. However, links or references to this site may be freely posted.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Phoenix metropolitan area in Arizona, USA

contact.organizationName: Global Institute of Sustainability, Arizona State University

section.title: Photosynthesis measurements
section.para: Diurnal gas exchange measruements were made seasonally on C3 woody plants on clear days during four, 3-h time intervals veginning at 0700, 1000, 1300 and 1600 h and ending by dusk. Diurnal measurements were made during four consecutive climatic seasons: late summer monsoon (August/September), winter (December), spring (March), and early summer dry (June).Monthly gas exchange measurements were made at all sites on dominant C3 plants of three life-forms: trees, shrubs, and ground covers. The most recently physiologically mature plant tissues were chosen and consisted of partial leaves, whole leaves, or small shootsegments 3-7 nodes from the apical meristem.

Gas exchange measurements were made with 1/4 liter hand held changer connected to a protable infrared gas analyzer, operating in closed-system mode. Each sample measurement involved an open system exhaustion of system air and replacemet with ambiend air followed by two consecutive 15s obersvations in closed-system mode to minimize changes in the chamber micro-environment during the sampling interval. During measurements, internal system airflow was regulated to minmize changes in chamber temperature and relative humidity.
The chamber thermocouple was positioned in direct contact with the abaxial surface of measured leaves and stems.
Leaf and shoot surface areas used in teh calculations of gas exchange flux values were measrued with a digitizing carea system interfaced to a computer.

section.title: Water potential measurements
section.para: Pre-dawn water potential of three randomly chosen shoot segments from each plant was measured usting a Scholander Type pressure bomb.

section.title: Plant relative water content measurements
section.para: Shoot relative water content (RWC) was measure on two samples of each plant throughout the same measuring period as photosynthesis measurements. Fresh weight (FW) is determined, then each shoot is placed in water saturating conditions for 72 hrs. After determining saturated weight (SW), shoots were placed in a drying oven for 72 hrs at 60 C and dry weight (DW) was determined. Shoot RWC was calculated s (FW-DW)div(SW-DW).

ns2:unit.name: micromolePerMeterSquaredPerSecond
ns2:unit.ns2:description: micro Einsteins (1E-06 moles of photons) per square meter per second (radiant flux density). It is also called the energy possessed by one mole or Avogadro number of photons.

ns2:unit.name: millimolePerMeterSquaredPerSecond
ns2:unit.ns2:description: milli-Einsteins (1E-03 moles of photons) per square meter per second (radiant flux density). It is also called the energy possessed by one mole or Avogadro number of photons.

ns2:unit.name: molePerMeterSquaredPerSecond
ns2:unit.ns2:description: Einsteins (moles of photons) per square meter per second (radiant flux density). It is also called the energy possessed by one mole or Avogadro number of photons.
